content.description:
The hand crack through the smaller section of the roof

Left side of the crag
Gear to 2"

Wide, left-leaning crack to the right of Thrombosis. Fists and hands, but at an easy grade. Not too engaging for an experienced climber, but for a beginner it's never too early to learn proper jamming technique and it *is* splitter.

To the right of the deep groove in the middle of the crag that is Thrombosis.
I placed a #4 and a #2. You could place more. 3/8" bolts the top, so when you're done I'd advise cleaning your anchor and walking to the big tree and rapping off.

The right hand crack through the wider section of the roof. 

Gear to 2".

While this route looks like an ugly offwidth battle, the crack is featured enough on the sides to climb like a jughaul. There are maybe two legitimate jams needed, the rest is edges and jugs. The crux is actually after the chimney, when you need to pull into the upper crack - the chimney is maybe 5.7. Starting to get scruffy again, so climb it! Deep, wide, chimney-like groove to the right of Thorax Complaint. I placed two #4s, a blue metolius and a #2 Camalot above the break. You could probably get away with a standard rack - there's enough options around to climb this safely without anything bigger than a #2.

3/8" bolts at the top that I wouldn't rap from. I'd recommend cleaning your anchor, walking to the big tree and rapping from that. (Or belay from the top so and you and your partner can follow the shortcut at the top of the crag to Funarama.)

This small crag features a small variety of climbs from 5.4-5.12+. It is less popular than surround crags, so a good alternative for busy days when octopus' garden and funorama are too crowded.  Its main attraction is two of the only 5.10 roof cracks in the bluffs.
